Favorable_Influences: Extremely attractive location.
Remarks: This is an exceptionally fine residential area containing nothing but large, expensive homes on extensive plots. The latter are well landscaped and there is a distinct pride of ownership in evidence. Mortgage lenders favor this area because of the stability of the owners, but the market for such propoerties is almost nil.

Favorable_Influences: Attractiveness of development and convenience of location.
Detrimental_Influences: Somewhat unattractive outlook together with lack of sewers and stores.
Remarks: This is a new, speculative development of moderately sized homes and lots, of which the only vacancies are those remaining unsold. Architecture is very pleasing and pride of ownership is excellent. Vacant hillside land separates this form less desirable area to the southwest. There is competition among lenders to place money in this location.

Terrain_Description: Hillside land sloping to the lake
Favorable_Influences: Attractiveness of Location
Remarks: This is a very desirable, residential section. Whereas some are of fair size the majority of homes are both modest and modern. Plots, in proportion to dwellings, are well landscaped and cared for. Larger homes almost never appear in the rental market. It is considered to be a good area for mortage money

Favorable_Influences: Extremely attractive location.
Remarks: This is an Exceptionally fine residential area containing nothing but large, expensive homes on extensive plots. The latter are well landscaped and there is a distinct pride of ownership in evidence. Mortgage lenders favor this area because of the stability of the owners, but the market for such properties is almost nil.

Terrain_Description: Hillside land sloping to the lake.
Favorable_Influences: Attractiveness of location.
Remarks: This is a very desirable, residential section. Whereas some are of fair size the majority of homes are both modest and modern. Plots, in proportion to dwellings, are well landscaped and cared for. Larger homes almost never appear in the rental market. It is considered to be a good area for mortgage money.

Terrain_Description: Known as Small Isle. Land is level and partly filled in. (Artificially made by pumping sand in from the bay). Well landscaped and good growth of trees
Favorable_Influences: Zoned for residential and highly restricted. Near exclusive golf course; good scenic features (overlooking Tampa Bay). Desirable water fraontage. Street car and bus service to Isle (used principally by servants). Schools, churches and community business centers about q mile distant. All streets paved.
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy weed growth on vancant lots during summer.
INHABITANTS_Type: Business men and executives; retired business men and professional men
Remarks: About 25 houses in the area. Immediately adjoining this area east is another about the same size consisting of artificially made land which has been landscaped, streets paved, and is repe for future park development. Good residential area although at the present time no houses have been erected

Terrain_Description: Northern portion of area called Granada Terrace; remainder known as North Shore Drive. Land is level, with some of same filled in (artificially made land).
Favorable_Influences: Near exclusive golf course; good scenic features overlooking Tampa Bay/ Dersirable water frontage/ Street car and bus service through area to Shell Island for servants. Zoned for residential and highly restricted. Schools, churches, and community business centers about one mile distant. All streets paved.
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy weed growth on vancant lots during summer.
INHABITANTS_Type: Executives and business men; retired business and professional men.
Remarks: About 100 houses in this section. Wide range of family income in the area is due to the fact that quite a few wealthy families live in the area; some of these families are local people, while others are out of State residents who own homes in the area and occumpy same during the winter season

Favorable_Influences: Street car line to edge of area (used principally by servants). Zoned for residential and highly restricted. Methodist Church in area. All streets paved. Well Landscaped
Detrimental_Influences: Distance from center of city (3 miles). Surrounded by cheap type of property, occupied by mediocre type of inhabitants. Area has poor outlook to north and east. Heavy weed growth on vacant lots during summer. Poor approach to are.
INHABITANTS_Type: Executives and business men; retired business and professional men.

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions are known as Peacock Woods (A-1); Dinglewood (A-2); best portion of Woodcrest (A-3); and best portion of Overlook (A-4). A-4 is outside of city limits. Land is rolling in all areas except A-4, which is practically level.
Favorable_Influences: Lots are nicely landscaped, all streets paved except in A-4. A-1 has extremely large lots with rigid building restrictions, while the other areas have good good-size lots and good buiding restrictions. All areas except A-4 are conveniently located to schools, parks, and have good bus transportation facilities. All utilities are in all areas and all are conveniently located to community business section.
Detrimental_Influences: A-4 is inconveniently located to schools and bus transportation.
INHABITANTS_Type: Executive, retired business men and professional men
Remarks: A-1 is exclusive residential section.  A-1 contains about 15 houses, A-2 about 5, A-3 about 10, and A-4 about 10 making a total of approximately 40 houses in these four areas.  In A-4 on the south side of Edgewood Drive, between Benning Boulevard and Brookwood Avenue, are located one or two properties whose repair condition entitles them to C grade rating.

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions are Rock Park, Wynton Heights, and Boulevard Terrace (B-1); Wildwood Circle and remaining portion of Woodcrest (B-3); Wynton south of Macon Road, Oakview, and remaining portion of Overlook (B-2); Weracoba Heights (B-4); St. Elmo (B-5); Cherokee Heights (B-6). Land is these areas is rolling and hilly, except in B-2 and B-5, where the land is level and sloping
Favorable_Influences: All public utilities in. About 60% streets paved. All areas zoned and restricted. Proximity of the areas to schools, parks, play-grounds, and commmunity business centers. All areas except B-3 and B-6 have adequate bus transportation.
Detrimental_Influences: B-6 is adversely affected because of distance from schools, churches, buses, and community centers.
Remarks: B-1 has about 40 houses; B-2 about 50; B-3 about 50; B-4 about 100; B-5 about 150; B-6 about 10, making a total of approximately 400 houses in these 6 areas. Jumping of a color grade along the southwestern boundary of B-2 (Blue to red) is explained by the fact that this portion of B-2 is on the top of a high hill which drops off abruptly to the adjoining negro property (d-4) below the crest of the hill.  There is one large multiple unit apartment house in B-3.  In the southeastern section of B-2, along both sides of Buena Vista Road, beginnign at Brown Avenue and extending about 2 blocks west, are a group of properties whose poor repair condition places same in the D classification, instead of B as shown by the map; also in this same area on the northeast corner of Edgewood Drive and Benning Boulevard are one or two large properties which should be classified as C grade property. In B-3 from 16th to 17th Streets east of Wildwood Avenue, are several large old properties which should be classified as C grade property

In B-3 from 16th to 17th Streets east of Wildwood Avenue, are several large old properties which should be classified as C grade property

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions in this area are known as Evans Manor and Rosehill Heights.  The land in same is slightly rolling.
Favorable_Influences: All utilities in. Moderate restrictions.  Play-ground in area and new $300,000 Industrial High School, recently completed, adjoins the area on the eastern side.
Detrimental_Influences: Less than 10% of the streets are paved.  Distance from community business centers, main business section of Columbus, and churches.
INHABITANTS_Type: City employees, skilled mechanics, and clerical workers
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Slightly upward temporarily on account of new school, then static later on
Remarks: (a) There are about 40 houses in this area at the present time.  About 30 of same have been built since 1929 and about 10 of this 30 have been completed since Jan. 1, 1937.  In 1929 there were no paved streets in the area, which was then about 3/4 miles distant from adequate bus transportation as well as schools.  Due principally to the erection of the new Industrial High School, the new residential construction in the area is of a higher type than that of the residence originally built in the area and, consequently, demands a better rental price. (b) Generally speaking, insurance companies will not lend in this area, but local individual lenders, building and loan associations , and "Federals" will, although at a slightly higher rate than in the other B areas (about 6%).

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions are the old portion of Wynnton and Old Wynnton Heights.  The land in this area is all high, with some rolling and some level.
Favorable_Influences: Community business center and restrictions in most of the area, good schools, play-ground and adequate bus transportation.  All utilities in.  About 90% of streets paved.
Detrimental_Influences: Distance from churches.  Heavy traffic conditions along Wynnton Road.
INHABITANTS_Type: Mixed, varying from business executives and professional men to retired Army people.
Remarks: (a) Less than a dozen sales occurred in this area at the low, hence difficult to fix sale values at low.  This area contains heterogeneous and spotted residential property.  Some of the property should receive a B grade, the location of these groups of property are on the north side of Buena Vista Road, in the easter portion of Dinglewood; the eastern side of 16th Avenuue, from Wynnton Road to the alley north of 12th Street; and the northwest corner of Wynnton Road and Peacock Avenue.  Also in this area, on the west side of Britt Avenue, midway between Wynnton Road and Schaul Street, is located the community fire station and a group of Negro rental property adjoining expensive residential property which fronts Wynnton Road.

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions in this area are Britt Addition, East Wynnton, Tate Survey and Wynnton & Blakenship Survey.  The land is practically level.
Favorable_Influences: Proximity to Wynnton School, playgrounds, churches, and community business center.  All utilities in.  Adequate bus transportation.
Detrimental_Influences: Building restrictions only medium.  Only about 20% of the streets are paved.
Remarks: (a)Rental prices did not go lower because of Army people at depression low furnished stronger rental demands than would ordinarily have prevailed.  Most lenders restrict their loans in this area.  At the northeast corner of Lawyer's Lane and Marion STreet are located one or two fine residences which are superior to the other property in the area and deserve a B rating.  Also in this area, on the south side of Wynnton Road, just east of Tate Drive, are a group of Negro houses, with another group located on the east side of Britt Avenue, between Schaul and Marion Streets. On both sides of Francis Street, between Lawyer's Lane and Ada Avenue, are several properties whose repai condition entitles them to a D grade rating.

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions are the eastern portion of East Highlands (C-3); Delaney Place (C-4); Waverly Terrace, and part of Rosehill Heights (C-5); Rosehill (C-6).  The land is partly rolling and partly level, with the majorty level.
Favorable_Influences: Good schools, churches, play-grounds and bus facilities.  All utilities in.
Detrimental_Influences: Lack of zoning and poor building restrictions in C-6; other areas only fair in this respect.  Advanced age and poor repair condition of properties in C-3 to C-6, inclusive.  About 40% of streets paved in these four areas.
INHABITANTS_Type: Skilled mechanics, city employees, and clerical workers
INHABITANTS_Infiltration: Only in C-3 and 6 of lower income bracket
Remarks: (a) Insurance companies will not lend in these areas and local lenders will only lend on a restricted basis. In C-5 many of the properties located on both sides of 10th Avenue, from 31 to 32 Streets and both sides of 32 Street, from 10th to 11th Avenues, are in such poor repair condition as to rate a D grading.  A similar group of property is located at the northeast and southeast corners of 33rd Street and 12th Avenue.  There is a small business section located at the intersection of River and Hamilton Roads.  In C-6 there is a small business section located on Hamilton Road, from  26th to 29th Streets.

Terrain_Description: Principal subdivisions are the eastern portion of East Highlands (C-3); Delaney Place (C-4); Waverly Terrace, and part of Rosehill Heights (C-5); Rosehill (C-6).  The land is partly rolling and partly level, with the majorty level.

Terrain_Description: A-1 is know as Shirley Hills; A-2 known as Stanislaus. A-1 is level; A-2 hilly and rolling. About 35 houses in A-1; 25 in A-2.
Favorable_Influences: Newest high residential sections; proximity to good schools, churches, playgrounds, and parks. Highly restricted, all utilities in. A-1 has scenic features and about 5 percent of streets paved. Both sections comprised of homes of above average construction, modern, and of the type readily marketable. All streets paved in A-2.
Detrimental_Influences: Main line of Central of Georgia Rwy. About 200' in rear of back lots in A-2 is not considered detrimental because track is 40 feet below level of subdivision.
Remarks: A-1 is outside the city and has average lots of about 1 acre. Lots in A-2 range from 60 to 100 feet frontage. Both subdivisions were developed about 1927. Red area D-12 is separated from A-2 by railroad in deep cut. Yellow area C-2 is older type property; not as highly restricted as A-2.

Terrain_Description: A-1 is know as Shirley Hills; A-2 known as Stanislaus. A-1 is level; A-2 hilly and rolling. About 35 houses in A-1; 25 in A-2.
Favorable_Influences: Newest high residential sections; proximity to good schools, churches, playgrounds, and parks. Highly restricted, all utilities in. A-1 has scenic features and about 5 percent of streets paved. Both sections comprised of homes of above average construction, modern, and of the type readily marketable. All streets paved in A-2.
Detrimental_Influences: Main line of Central of Georgia Rwy. About 200' in rear of back lots in A-2 is not considered detrimental because track is 40 feet below level of subdivision.
Remarks: A-1 is outside the city and has average lots of about 1 acre. Lots in A-2 range from 60 to 100 feet frontage. Both subdivisions were developed about 1927. Red area D-12 is separated from A-2 by railroad in deep cut. Yellow area C-2 is older type property; not as highly restricted as A-2.

Terrain_Description: Known as Ingleside, Ingleside Addition, Forsyth Circle, and Roycrest. Level to hilly. About 230 houses in this area.
Favorable_Influences: Proximity to good grade schools and community stores. Good bus transportation facilities. Ample park and recreational facilities; good scenic features. Building restrictions range from $3,500 to $5,000. No city taxes.
Detrimental_Influences: Septic tanks in Forsythn Cirlce and Roycrest, with special sewer and garbage disposal charges in remainder of area. No paved streets other than Forsyth Road. Distance from high school (3 miles). Outside city, hence not subject to city building inspection; inadequate police and fire protection. Heavy traffic alon Forsyth Road (18' wide).
Remarks: Red area D-1, known as Crumps Park comprises a section 100% built up of old homes of cheap construction; city's development began at outskirts of this area D-1 and grew northward with better type of construction predominating. B-1, separated by deep railroad out from red area D-8. There is a small cluster of negro rental units located at end of Auburn Road and Belvedere Drive, along east side of Overlook Avenue. There are a number of one and two-story residences fronting on Vista Circle which would justify a higher rating, were it not for the fact that the general character of the neighborhood tends to give same a lower rating.

Terrain_Description: B-2 is known as De Soto Park and B-3 is known as Beverly Place. Land is level and sloping. About 60 houses in B-2; 15 in B-3.
Favorable_Influences: Good transportation facilities, community stores, grade schools, and churches. B-3 has all utilities in. both areas well restricted.
Detrimental_Influences: Only Vineville Avenue paved in B-2. Special swere and garbage disposal charges in B-2, as well as inadequate fire and police protection. Proximity to railroad, lumber mill and cotton mills (all across tracks). Georgia Academy for Blind near B-2 is not a detriment. 1 as in B-3 have insufficient depth. Heavy traffic on Vineville Avenue.
Remarks: Homes along Texas Avenue in B-2 are not as high type as remainder of area.

Terrain_Description: B-2 is known as De Soto Park and B-3 is known as Beverly Place. Land is level and sloping. About 60 houses in B-2; 15 in B-3.
Favorable_Influences: Good transportation facilities, community stores, grade schools, and churches. B-3 has all utilities in. both areas well restricted.
Detrimental_Influences: Only Vineville Avenue paved in B-2. Special swere and garbage disposal charges in B-2, as well as inadequate fire and police protection. Proximity to railroad, lumber mill and cotton mills (all across tracks). Georgia Academy for Blind near B-2 is not a detriment. 1 as in B-3 have insufficient depth. Heavy traffic on Vineville Avenue.
Remarks: Homes along Texas Avenue in B-2 are not as high type as remainder of area.

Terrain_Description: Known as combination of Bill Davis, Calloway, and English property, plus both sides of Vineville Avenue from Hollow Avenue to Rogers Avenue. From level to sloping. About 200 houses in the area. [Text is approximate due to obstruction]
Favorable_Influences: Proximity to schools, churches, and community business centers. Good transportation facilities.  All utilities in.
Detrimental_Influences: About 50% of streets paved. Heavy traffic along Vineville Avenue. Built up 100% to city limits. Scattering of older houses in area, not entirely obsolete. Last block of Hines Terrace and Buford Place are low level, subject to overflow after heavy rains. [Text is approximate due to obstruction]
INHABITANTS_Type: business men, clerical workers and some executives
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Stable for next ten years, ten slowly downward, depending upon growth and development of Macon.
Remarks: Predominance of modern type residences influential in giving area stable rating. Negro settlement known as Berthadale (Berthadale) is about 300 yeards east of this area and is far enough removed from B-4 to not exact a detrimental influence on the area; 10 years is maximum term for lenders in this area (60% loans at 6%), except Title II loans, which can be obtained on 80% basis for 20 year term (only new construction). Most of the high class residences and higher income resident are confined to area consisting of both sides of Vineville Road from Rogers Avenue to Stonewell Place. [Text is approximate]

Terrain_Description: Known as Cherokee Heights and Cherokee Gardnes. Mostly rolling slightly level in places. There are about 245 houses in the area.
Favorable_Influences: Good schools, churches, community centers, playgrounds, transportation facilities. All utilities in. Restricted for home use.
Detrimental_Influences: About 10% of streets paved in Cherokee Heights; none in Cherokee Gardens. Presence of negro houses and mill houes along northeastern protion of area acts as detrimental influence to property located in northeastern section of area. Southern portion of Cherokee Gardens adjoins cheaper grade white property in area D-3.
INHABITANTS_Type: Business men, clerical workers and skilled mechanics
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Stable for next few years, then slowly downward.
Remarks: Cherokee Gardens is newer section than Cherokee Heights and contains houses of less substantial construction, but has greater sales demand at lower than the Cherokee Heights average price level. Cherokee Heights is nearly 100% built up. Sales demand in the area is less than that of any other B area.

Terrain_Description: Known as the best section of North Highlands. Land is level and rolling. There are about 115 houses in this area.
Favorable_Influences: Good scenic features; also good schools, churches, parks, playgrounds, shopping centers, and bus transportation facilities. Readily accessible to downtown area. All utilities in. Restricted solely for home use.
Remarks: Norther portion of red area D-10 abutting eastern portion of B-5 is undeveloped and probability of utilization for residential purposes rendered remote because of physical contour of terrain (steep bank and open creek).

Terrain_Description: Flat and high. East end is known as "Riverside."
Favorable_Influences: Most favorable secion of the city except for the ultra-rich. The two large areas in white without marking are forty-acre estates holding homes worth $100,000 each.
Next to area B-1, this is the city's most desirable section. There has been considerable remodeling and new construction.
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Desirable area; should hold up well.

Favorable_Influences: Thirty feet above the river. Well restricted. Not more than one or two houses valued below $3000.
Highly restricted. Homes $25,000 and up.
Detrimental_Influences: None of the homes would bring within $10,000 of cost. Limited market for expensive homes in this small city.

Favorable_Influences: None
Detrimental_Influences: Houses very generally do not have flush toilets. Houses are crowded. No sewers. "Jerry-built"--No basements.
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Declining, and probably should be in "red", except that it is new. Mortgage money is

Terrain_Description: Level, clay, gravel and stone.  Rolling land east of Wilcox with many old shade trees.
Favorable_Influences: Farragut School, and trend of growth in this area, and west.
Remarks: Vacant lots are in fair demand in this area.  On Campbell and Wilcox is a brick apartment of 20 units, well kept up.  Around Raynor and Mason are 3 brick apartments from 5-8 units, well kept up.  And there are several 2 unit brick and a few frame interspersed throughout the area.  East of Raynor and south of Western is oldest part of area, and from Prairie west there are no pavements except Western which is paved to Reed St, otherwise area has all utilities.  The western part of area from Reed St. to Midland Ave. between Mayfield and Glenwood has temporary sewers only - reported as being remedied by W.P.A at this time.  There are many _old frame homes_ interspersed throughout the area.  The extreme N.W. section of area if outside city limits.  All sections of area marked undeveloped on the west has no city sewers or water.

Favorable_Influences: None.
Remarks: Outside city limits.  Have local water and sewage system. Bus transportation only fair. Known as Maynor Park.

Terrain_Description: Level - few trees in eastern end but beautiful trees in western section.
Favorable_Influences: Attractive planning - adjacent Country Club - best school in city. Transportation (every 30 minutes) by bus.
Detrimental_Influences: No stores convenient, no churches nearby.
Remarks: Paving assessments were high because unnecessary expense of layout. In some cases the amount of special assessments exceed the price of the lot.

Favorable_Influences: Well planned. Scenic features good. Overlooking Packard Park.
Detrimental_Influences: Churches, stores, schools, not conveniently near.
Remarks: This area is on the so-called "west side" not easy of access and has been slow in developing for that reason.

Favorable_Influences: School nearby in A-1 area. Transportation through area. Shade trees plentiful.
Remarks: This is the very best blue section.

Favorable_Influences: Grade school in area - churches - transportation through the area - bus line. Zoning restrictions.
Remarks: Lots in this area are of good size. East Junior High School and Warren City Hospital in this area.

Favorable_Influences: High School in area.  Grade school across street from the area in C-7 (Elm Road School)
Detrimental_Influences: Fair grounds in center between Atlantic and Woodland Avenue.
Remarks: In 1929 this section was not so well developed as it is now. Also opening of Genessee Blvd. from E. Market to Elm Road, and of Woodland Avenue _to the Country Club_ has improved values in the area. The expensive homes in this area are generally along Fairmot & Bonnie Brae, Genessee.

Favorable_Influences: Close to city fine shade trees, Central Jr. High School in area, churches, nearby shopping centers. Near the High School.  Park adjacent to Perkins Circle.
Remarks: Best section of area is at extreme west - Perkins Drive, deserving Grade A but too small to be separate area.

Favorable_Influences: Adjacent to Packard Park. Roosevelt School in area.
Detrimental_Influences: Possible influx of lower grade population from C-6
Remarks: about 6 very expensive homes along Nahoning at south end of area.

Favorable_Influences: A good residential neighborhood, close to the business center.  Community spirit evident. Double drive up Iddings.  Known as Iddings Park.
Remarks: Slavish Catholic Church just out of the area at the northwest which may have tendency to concentrate Slavish into C-2 and thence into B-7.

Favorable_Influences: Schools nearby in C-2 and C-7.  Churches conveniently near in C-2.  Walking distance of shopping center.  Shade trees.
Detrimental_Influences: Proximity to R.R. and industry on north.
Remarks: Sunlight new plant (G.W.) will be built just north of this area.

Terrain_Description: Level with slight rise eastward on Market Street.  Slight depression of land along the railroad between Chestnut and Linden.  Near shopping districts and within walking distance of Republic Mill.  Grade School in area.  Churches in area.
Remarks: Some large houses used as rooming houses along Porter & High Streets. Many owners moved out and rented their houses - holding them for a rise because of business encroaching.  Central Jr. High School in area, also St. Mary's Catholic Church, Elm Road School.

Terrain_Description: Level - higher than business district and Mahoning Avenue side of the river.
Favorable_Influences: Some restrictions.  Bus transportation is regular (30 minutes intervals)
Detrimental_Influences: No schools, no stores, no churches.  Necessary to cross railroad to go into area.
Remarks: Southeastern part of area older - poorly planned except North Todd which is good. Garden Street along R.R. has houses 50 years old poor to fair condition.  New street in - not shown on map about 30 houses on this street.

Terrain_Description: Slopes slightly north from Railroad, otherwise level and high from east to west.
Favorable_Influences: 5 Churches - 2 schools, nearby stores along W. Markwet, Parkman and Mason Streets. Transportation by bus along both north and south boundaries.
Detrimental_Influences: Concentration of negroes and foreign at western extremity on Nevada, Oregon and McNyler Streets.  Commercial encroachment along W. Market and Summit Streets.
Remarks: East of York Street nearly all American inhabitants

Terrain_Description: Generally level with very slight slope toward river.
Favorable_Influences: West side Jr. High School Palmyra & Austin, 3 churches. Neighborhood stores along Market, Highland Avenue, Quinby Park.
Detrimental_Influences: Southeastern portion of the area characterized by foreign and negro.
INHABITANTS_Type: Factory workers, merchants and business men
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Static except in west extremity where possibly up.
Remarks: About 200 bungalows west of Austin.  Todd Avenue out of city limits (south) good prospects for favorable development.

Favorable_Influences: Roosevelt School, 1 grade. Not far to factories, General Motors Plant, Ohio Lamp Factory, etc.
Remarks: Good transportation, close to factories, school and churches, also Fire Station in area,

Favorable_Influences: Schools in area.  Close to High School in B-4 area. Adjacent to factories (for those who work in factories).
Remarks: Foreigners likely to invade this area.  Home Savings & Loan Companies of Youngstown, also Trumbull, had about 50 foreigners in this area which were offered for sale in October 1936.  All closed out now.  Prices average 3500, the amount of the mortgage.

Favorable_Influences: Factories near northeast section of this area. Restrictions - zoning residential.  School, some churches.  Stores adjacent on Niles Road & Youngstown Road.
Remarks: Section is "killed" by influx of negroes from D-3 to attend Francis Wilard School in C-8.

Terrain_Description: Flat - lowest built up section of city
Favorable_Influences: Close to mill.  Business center available. Schools near, within walking distance of shopping center.
Detrimental_Influences: Concentration of disorderly houses along Fulton Street. Heavy paving assessment on Fulton Street, So. Park Ave., Walnut Street.  Low grade population.
Remarks: Rent decline due to improvidence of occupants.  All work in Republic Steel, about 3 blocks away from the area.

Favorable_Influences: Near Republic Streel Mill.  Neighborhood stores.
Detrimental_Influences: Old property - Overflow at times of high water, no schools.
Remarks: Not quite as good as D-1, 20% lower rentals, 50% lower sales values.  City dump adjacent to the property on west.  Dump between Hayden and Steele Sts.

Terrain_Description: Flat but high enough to secure from floods.
Favorable_Influences: Air Reduction Sales Company.  Chicago Car Roofing Co. One Steel Mill also in area.  School but no churches. Bus transportation
Detrimental_Influences: B&O Railroad & Erie R.R. pass through area.  Some streets unimproved.
Remarks: Section was built arund old Western Reserve Steel Mill. This mill is gone now.  This section probably worst in the city.

Favorable_Influences: Proximity to Packard, Sunlight, Warren City Tank & Boiler Co. Grinnell Company, Youngstown Pressed Steel etc.
Detrimental_Influences: Very bad planning and poorly built homes.
Remarks: Warren City Tank & Boiler Company has office south central section of this area.  Loan commitments about 20% of appraisals here.  Area has slight tendency to increase of colored population.

Favorable_Influences: The most desirable section of Altoona in point of location, class of people, homogeneity of development and freedom from objectionable influences. Good transportation and schools.
Detrimental_Influences: None except heavy traffic on Union Ave.
Remarks: Only 2 sales in past five years have been made in this section. This section is a good first grade neighborhood well protected against undesireable encroachment. Houses are built on large lots and set well back from the street.

Favorable_Influences: Very desirable residential, well located and well planned, character of this area is good. Good transportation and schools.
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy traffic on Union Ave. through the section.
Remarks: This section is similar in general character to section A-1, although somewhat older and more extensively developed. Additional building will ensue in this neighborhood as general economic conditions improve.

Favorable_Influences: Quiet and clean neighborhood of good character with desirable housing. Homogeneous as to development on fair size lots. Good transportation and schools.
Detrimental_Influences: None except distance to center of city.
Remarks: This is a good second grade section which is well protected against undesirable encroachment. Mortgage money would certainly be available on favorable terms if the local institutions were in a position to loan. This neighborhood is distinctly suburban in character with houses fairly well spaced.

Favorable_Influences: Section enjoys a very good reputation. Desirable and well planned area of good houses on good sized lots. Good transportation & Schools.
Remarks: In point of desirability this is a first grade section, but in view of age and general appearance of the housing the section rates only good second grade. Area enjoys a good reputation and is similar in general character to section A-1, but ground values are lower and the housing is not kept in as fine condition. A foreign section backs up to Ruskin Ave. properties, but is reputed to have little affect on this neighborhood.

Favorable_Influences: A desirable area of modest homes in a clean and quiet neighborhood. Section enjoys good character. Convenient to two new factories along RR tracks.
Detrimental_Influences: Poor transportation and schools at lower end.
INHABITANTS_Type: Business & Professional men Few RR Trainmen
Remarks: Upper end of the section is better. Executives of two new factories (Glass plant & silk mill) are locating in this section. Houses are substantially build and well spaced.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation and schools. Near center of city. Desirable section with good reputation.
Remarks: An old section of Altonna which continues to enjoy a good reputation. Some converted houses in the area. Cheaper units are distress property. Financing through F. H. A. is not available because of small lots. Many old families still residing in orginial houses. A fair to poor second grade section which has retained its residential desirability.

Favorable_Influences: Good transprotation and schools. Good reputation of area. Substantial neighborhood.
Remarks: Few foreclosures with few distress sales which helped hold up prices. Some reconditioning is improving neighborhood. Favorably affected by proximity to section A-2.

Favorable_Influences: Quiet and clean suburban development of good character. Houses are substantially built on good sized lots. Good transportation.
Detrimental_Influences: No shopping center. Distance to schools.
Remarks: This was a promotional development by a local operator who sold the lots to young business men of Altoona. The section has held up rather well and is considered a very desirable neighborhood. Heavy foreclosures in this area.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation - Near school, clean and quiet neighborhood.
Detrimental_Influences: Crossing of high speed throughfare to grade school. Distance from center of city
Remarks: Entire area was developed by an operation builder. The section is a very desirable residential area for shopmen in R.R. repair plants. This is a modest neighborhood of fair housing.

Favorable_Influences: Exclusive neighborhood
Remarks: The area is asristocractic. Pride of ownership is very good. All construction for specific individuals, no operative building.

Favorable_Influences: Desirable restricted residential area of high class homes - good transportation and schools
Remarks: The majority of the homes are priced under $15,000. Considerable rivalry exists between this section and section A-3 and A-4 for choicest development.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation and schools - restricted section of modest character.
Remarks: Property values taper off as they recede from the lake shore. Lincoln Ave. is a very old street but very desirable with homes up to 40 years of age.  One man owns and controls a large percent of the properties in this section.  On Maryland, south of Superior Ave. Shenley and Beverly Streets are new modern brick and frame cottages not quite up to the standard of the balance of the section.

Favorable_Influences: Near schools - Homogeneous development of good character.  Restricted section well-planned with good elevation.
Remarks: Continued building activity may be anticipated in this section - probably the most active of any area in Erie.

Favorable_Influences: Restricted residential section of fairly new houses of good character.  Near park.  Good view.
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: A summer cottage development primarily with some few very good homes interspersed through the area.  Some concentration of houses is centered along West Lake Road and West 12th Street.  Development will be slow because of the location, although for summer cottages some activity may be anticipated.  The vacant ground not presently built on is being farmed.  Area is outside the city limits of Erie.  Mortgage funds in the area are limited as to type of structure and very little high-class construction of a permanent home nature is anticipated
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: A sparsely settled section with few houses scattered throughout.  The majority of the housing is concentrated along 26th Street.  The balance of the section, although surveyed, is practically all being farmed at present.  Development will be very slow, but of fair character when such happens.  Section is outside the city limits of Erie.
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation and schools - Close to an industrial section nearby within walking distance.
Remarks: Favorably affected by proximity to sections A-1 and A-2.

Favorable_Influences: Central location - only good downtown residential section
Detrimental_Influences: Somewhat old - heavy traffic through section
Remarks: Considerable business of small nature scattered throughout section.  Many wealthy people are moving out.  Section is very spotty but retains its desirability as a residential area.  Many good modern apartments in this section.  Graded second grade principally because of location and stable demand for property.  6th and 10th were originally developed with very high grade homes which are still in excellent condition.

Favorable_Influences: Good schools and transportation - convenient to shopping area.
Remarks: Section is somewhat spotty with many original owners still living in section.  Sales are poor but have improved since early 1937.

Favorable_Influences: Good schools and transportation
Remarks: Property south of 26th Street is considered to be more desirable than that on the north.  There is considerable business on the dividing street.  Hazel and Maple Streets are not good with foreign coming in.  From Myrtle Street to Peach Street south of 26th, properties are below par of the section.

Favorable_Influences: Desirable residential section with good elevation.
Detrimental_Influences: Schools are lacking and children must pay tuition in city schools or commute to county schools.
Remarks: Section is building up slowly with fairly good houses.

Terrain_Description: Fairly level on top of hill
Favorable_Influences: Fairly new section well located - near park. Good elevation.
Remarks: A small section of good character well protected from encroachment.

Favorable_Influences: Homogenous development of good character. Fairly good transportation. Sections overlook Frick Park.
Detrimental_Influences: None except distance to commerical section.
Remarks: This is only a fair 1st grade section

Favorable_Influences: Highly desirable residential area - Good transportation and shopping center. Good elevation.
Remarks: One of the best sections in city limits. Houses from $15,000 to $25,000 predominate. Section is threatened with Jewish encroachement from the south. Forbes St. frontage is expected to be zoned for apartments.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation. Very good public and private schools. Well restricted. Zoned for best development.
Remarks: About 50% of this section is older houses and 50% fairly new. Very little room for expansion or new building except on divided estates.

Favorable_Influences: Near Park. Good general character of people and structures.
Remarks: Most of the rental units are duplexes. New building is on subdivided ground of large estates and older houses.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation. Old but but well established and desirable residential section. Near civic center.
Remarks: One of the few level sections in Pittsburgh. A very stable demand exists for property in this section. Large estates are being broken up and smaller units replacing very larg houses. Seciton is graded first grade because of activity and desirability of the area. Older houses at present are difficult to sell except where demolition is feasible and subdividing of ground profitable.

Terrain_Description: Hilly - rolling territory on top of mound
Favorable_Influences: Very desirable residential with high class populace
Remarks: All new construction built for specific individuals. Large country club located here. Atmosphere in general very good.

Favorable_Influences: Fairly new desirable residential areas with suburban atmosphere. Good bus service
Detrimental_Influences: None except distance to commercial area.
Remarks: Activity only started in past 15 months. Principally F.H.A financing on new construction.

Favorable_Influences: High social standard - Desirable better class housing. Good train & bus service.
Remarks: Some of Pittsburgh wealthier people own homes in this section.

Favorable_Influences: Homogenous development of good character. Good transportation. Very desirable residential section.
Detrimental_Influences: Same danger of mine cave causing houses to sag, particularly on the hill sides.
Remarks: Recent letting of contract to pave Banksville road will add another outlet for heavy traffic into this area. The foreclosures were very heavy throughout Mt. Lebanon. About 80% of the homes were mortgaged in 1934.

Terrain_Description: A section well outside the city limits which was well planned and well laid out.  Only three or four houses have been built to date, but the section appears to be of fairly good grade.  Development will necessarily be slow because of the distance to the city.  Mortgage financing should be conservative.
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Level to rolling in western end
Favorable_Influences: Good transportation-schools-churches
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation-schools-churches.Desirable residential section of good character
Remarks: Considered a high class medium-priced neighborhood which is favorably affected by adjacent Glen-wood Park section.

Favorable_Influences: Good location-good transportation- only new northeast side resedential section- convenient to east side plants- homogeneous high class development
Remarks: properties fronting on the lake are very good

Favorable_Influences: N/A
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Rolling / Called Williamson Groves & East Gate
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: Local predjudice against this area. Cheap construction. Unsuccessful attempt at suburban development.

Terrain_Description: Called Conehurst and Edgewood / Unsuccessful developments.
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Rolling steeply - Edge Hill / Outside the city limits
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Rolling steeply. Called Prospect Hill - Outside the city limits.
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Na
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Rolling Steeply. / Outside the city limits.
Favorable_Influences: Na
Remarks: NA

Terrain_Description: Level. / Best part Williamson Road section / This is outside the city limits
Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: A large percentage of current building is going on here at about $4,000-4,200 single family, brick veneer, hot water neat.

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: Still desireable for 5 years. Residents would rather be in B-3 and A-1-2-3 or 4.

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: Roanoke is R.H. center. A large area is bothered with train, noise and smoke. This section is free of this and several degrees cooler in summer months than other parts of the city. Along Broadway and along First Street, Second Street, and Third Street Broadway to Carolina and along Wellington Avenue, N & W R.R. to Third St. the property is older and generally in poorer condition than the balance of the area. Property on above mentioned streets is 3rd grade.

Favorable_Influences: Villa Heights and Grove Park and Rugby. The western tip is shown to be beyond the city limits.
Remarks: Approach through negro and poor white sections. Tendency or desire of occupants is to move toward B-1.

Favorable_Influences: Williamson Road. Outside the city limits.
Remarks: Approach through negro section. Borderson undesirable section. Unsuccessful development. Outlook unfavorable because of local prejudice against foreign born and heavy traffic over arterial highway.

Favorable_Influences: Williamson Road. Outside the city limits.
Remarks: Approach through negro section. Borderson undesirable section. Unsuccessful development. Outlook unfavorable because of local prejudice against foreign born and heavy traffic over arterial highway.

Favorable_Influences: New building
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: NA
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Labor from the N & W R.R. shops and VA.Bridge Plant
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Fairly new suburban area of homogeneous character. Well planned development. Fairly close to city shopping area. Near Parks. Near Schools.
Remarks: A recent development with much room for expansion directly to the north. Ground Rent $90-$120. Average $110. Much of this property has been built in past five years, especially on northern edge. Valuation changes do not include these properties.

Favorable_Influences: Very nicely planned residential area of medium to large homes. Direct transportation to center of city is good. Close to business area on Greenmount Ave.
Remarks: Mostly fee properties. A few homes valued at $10,000 to 15 000 along Homeland Avenue with Ground Rent up to $150

Favorable_Influences: Good residential area. Well planned.
Remarks: Principally fee property. This section lies in Baltimore County outside Baltimore City. Originally developed as expensive section, but recent houses have been lower priced, thus holding down values in higher priced units.

Favorable_Influences: Well planned development of fairly
Remarks: All fee property

Favorable_Influences: Desirable residential section. Good quality, medium priced section.
Remarks: Merridale only recently developed. Prices do not include Merridale. Principally fee property. Part of the section is outside Baltimore city limits.

Favorable_Influences: To be developed as high grade development
Remarks: Owned and controlled by the Roland Park Company. Developers apparently intend to keep the section comparable to Guilford. All fee property.

Favorable_Influences: Desirable old residential section. Principally large homes and well restricted
Remarks: This section was completely built up in 1921. All fee properties. Houses are hard to sell in this section, but character of area is good.

Favorable_Influences: Restricted, desirable residential section of moderately large houses on large lots. A wooded section of good character.
Remarks: Principally fee property.

Favorable_Influences: Good residential section of fast moving property.
Detrimental_Influences: Few streets of property in poor condition
Remarks: Section is very spotty with poor houses lying on low ground. Most of new development is on western edge. Ground rents are either $90 or $120

Favorable_Influences: Good suburban residential area of modest homes. A desirable section of good character.
Remarks: Ground rent range $90 to $120. Part of the section is outside Baltimore City limits

Favorable_Influences: Good residential section of homogeneous character.
Remarks: Ground rents $90 to $120. Principally $90.

Favorable_Influences: Near Druid Hill Park. Close to center of city.
Remarks: Three story houses on Reisterstown Road are 25 years old. Ground Rents $90 to $120. Predominating $96

Favorable_Influences: Stable residential section of modest homes.
Remarks: Ground rents $60 to $90. Predominating $84. Fair valuation

Favorable_Influences: Good residential area holding up in value
Remarks: Ground rents $72 to $120. Ground rents in Cedarcroft are principally $120

Favorable_Influences: Fairly good residential section with all conveniences.
Remarks: This section lies in Baltimore County just outside of Baltimore City. Ground rent $90 to $120. Principally $90. New houses are up to $10,000

Favorable_Influences: Desirable residential section, homogeneous as to development and general type of construction. Free of bad features. Substantial class of people.
Remarks: Considered the best lending section in the city. Ground rent $75 to $120. Averaging $95

Favorable_Influences: Homogeneous development. Near to parks. Transportation is good. All modest homes in good demand.
Remarks: Ground rents range from $72 to $95. Predominating $72.

Favorable_Influences: Near to Sparrows Point. Desirable residential section.
Detrimental_Influences: Distances to commercial area. Narrow streets.
Remarks: Very few Ground Rents in Dundalk. This section was developed for officers of Bethlehem Steel Company at Sparrows Point.

Favorable_Influences: Quiet suburban section of homogeneous character
Remarks: Principally fee property. Few ground rents $120

Favorable_Influences: Outlying quiet suburban section.
Detrimental_Influences: None except distances to center of city.
Remarks: Outside Baltimore City limits. A few larger homes in Sudbrook Park up to $20,000. Principally fee properties.

Favorable_Influences: Stable old residential section of good character.
Remarks: Many high-grade apartments are located along Charles and St. Paul streets. Ground rents range $90 to $150. Predominating $120

Favorable_Influences: Outlying quiet suburban section. County east of Baltimore County.
Remarks: Principally fee property

Favorable_Influences: Very high. Fairly new residential section of homogeneous development.
Remarks: Ground Rents range from $72 to $96. Predominating $90. A well developed and well planned section of modern homes.

Favorable_Influences: Desirable residential section of very good character
Remarks: Average held at $2000 to $2500 per acre. A sparsely settled area of high grade Americans. Fee properties.

Favorable_Influences: Suburban atmosphere. Desirable residential section
Remarks: A sparsely settled section of modest homes. Principally fee properties

Favorable_Influences: A fairly new development of single homes in desirable surroundings.
Remarks: This section has not taken the public's fancy and development appears to slow

Favorable_Influences: The natural section for expansion from Liberty Heights Ave development
Remarks: Still very sparsely settled, but may be expected to develop into good character.

Favorable_Influences: Desirable residential section of good character. Suburban atmosphere.
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Close to commercial area. Fairly desirable residential section near parks.
Remarks: Ground rents range from $50 to $50. Average $50. There is considerable business on main thoroughfares

Favorable_Influences: Stable residential area of modest houses.
Remarks: Ground rent range $60 to $90. This section has a concentration of medium income Jewish families. Cottages are not selling very well.

Favorable_Influences: Conversion value of location for business purposes. Commercial future.
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy traffic and disadvantage of commerce except as above
Ten_Fifteen_Desirability: Downward as residential, upward for commerce
Remarks: Ground rents $72 to $120. Average $90

Favorable_Influences: Outlying residential section of small modest homes
Remarks: Ground rent range $72 to $90.  Predominating. The general reputation of this section is fair, but the section embraces some poorly constructed houses.

Favorable_Influences: None
Remarks: Ground rents range $43 to $72. Average $60. Very spotty

Favorable_Influences: Proximity to industrial plants.
Remarks: Ground rents $30 to $75. Predominating $60

Favorable_Influences: Old residential section of modest character in poor condition. Near Druid Hill Park.
Remarks: Ground rent range $42 to $90. Predominating $60 to $72. Not a very desirable area.

Favorable_Influences: Fairly good residential section of modest homes
Remarks: Ground rent range $72 to $95. Predominating $90

Favorable_Influences: Proximity to Patterson Park. Near to industrial plants.
Detrimental_Influences: Substantial age and disadvantages of industry except as above
Remarks: This entire area is populated principally by persons of Polish extraction who have considerable pride of appearance of their property. Age of property necessitates the third grade. Ground rents in this area range from $42 to $72 and $42 to $48 predominates.

Favorable_Influences: Near to employment, particularly Sparrows Point
Detrimental_Influences: Distance to center of city. Smoke and noise from factories lack of planning in developments.
Remarks: Demand is expected to increase because of expansion at Sparrows Point. All fee properties. Portions of this section are outside city limits.

Favorable_Influences: Fairly desirable residential area of rather old houses. Close to commercial area
Remarks: Ground rents range from $48 to $75 and average $60

Favorable_Influences: Close to commercial area. Goucher college located in the section. Desirable location.
Detrimental_Influences: Industrial plants. Continuing obsolescence of old property
Remarks: Ground rents range from $75 to $150 and average. $90 to $110. Some of these properties are being converted into small apartment units and other are being used as boarding houses.

Favorable_Influences: Proximity to Druid Hill Park.
Detrimental_Influences: Obsolescence and negro encroachment. Ground rents are very large
Remarks: Houses are being converted into apartment units. Many rooms in the area are rented and few houses are used for boarding purposes. Some fine old homes are still housing original owners and have considerable values as such. Ground rents range from $90 to $300 average $90 to $120. Too high.

Favorable_Influences: Close to commercial area
Detrimental_Influences: Continuing obsolescence of old style houses.
Remarks: Ground rent $50 to $75 average $60. No immediate danger of negro encroachment, but there is a heavy concentration of Negros in the section adjoining. Section is somewhat spotty and has few ground rent up to $120

Favorable_Influences: NA
Detrimental_Influences: A mediocre section of cheap construction
Remarks: Very sparsely settled section

Favorable_Influences: Fairly good location
Remarks: The section never seemed to go over very well and is very sparsely settled

Favorable_Influences: Fairly desirable section of modest houses
Remarks: A rather presentable section of modest homes. Mostly fee property

Favorable_Influences: On Washington-Baltimore Pike
Detrimental_Influences: Loss of RR from the section
Remarks: Some utilities are lacking . Principally fee property

Favorable_Influences: Suburban atmosphere
Remarks: A sparsely settled section of fair character. Principally fee property.

Favorable_Influences: Similar in general character to Lansdowns (C-19)
Remarks: Principally fee property

Favorable_Influences: Similar in character to Lansdowne except further removed from the city limits.
Remarks: Principally fee property

Favorable_Influences: Similar in character to Lansdowne (C-19)
Remarks: NA

Favorable_Influences: Proximity to employment, industrial and commercial.
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy concentration of foreigners. Property is in very bad state of repair
Remarks: Ground rents in this section range from $36 to $60. Average $42. Properties around Johns Hopkins Hospital are better than the average and have considerable desirability in housing hospital attendants and for commercial value. Ground rents on Broadway. Sales are very poor. Section east of Broadway is better. Southern section largely industry. Whole section is spotty.

Favorable_Influences: Close to industrial employment.
Detrimental_Influences: Mixture of foreign born. Disadvantage of industry except as above.
Remarks: Area become worse south of Eastern Avenue. Ground Rents range $36 to $60. Predominately $36 to $48. Mixture of small industrial plants. Properties are old but fairly well maintained.

Favorable_Influences: Good transportation. Central location.
Detrimental_Influences: Obsolescence. Negro concentration. Excessive Ground Rents in many cases
Remarks: Ground rents range from $42 to $120. Predominating $60 and $75; considerable vandalism in this area. A few Ground Rents up to $200.

Favorable_Influences: Central location. Near employment.
Remarks: Ground rents in this section range from $30 to $60 and average $40 to $42.

Favorable_Influences: Near desirable properties.
Detrimental_Influences: Houses in very bad condition. Many alley properties. Area is run down.
Remarks: Ground rents range $30 to $60. Predominating $43 to $48. Vandalism in this section.

Favorable_Influences: Central locations. Conversion to business.
Detrimental_Influences: Interspersed with b business. Entire ward zoned for commerce.
Remarks: Valuations down do not include homes on Monument Square. A boarding house area with some very fine old homes still retaining considerable value around Mt. Vernon Place. Ground Rents range from $30 to $180. Ground rents on Mt. Vernon Place up to $216. Charles Street properties are the Central section includes some of the worst of some very good property.

Favorable_Influences: Central location. Conversion value for business expansion
Detrimental_Influences: Heavy obsolescence of residential property. Business noises.
Remarks: Most of this section comprises the commercial area of the city. Houses are intermingled with businesses. Ground Rents range from $30 to $90. Average $60. Alley property is very bad.
